de.team33.libs.typing.v3

Class Type<T>

  • java.lang.Object
    • de.team33.libs.typing.v3.Type<T>

  • public abstract class Type<T>
extends Object

    Represents a definite type description that can be based on a generic as well as a non-generic class. Examples:

    • an instance of Type<Map<String, List<String>>> represents the type Map<String, List<String>>.
    • an instance of Type<String> represents the type String.

    To get an instance of Type, you need to create a definite derivative of Type. The easiest way to achieve this is to use an anonymous derivation with simultaneous instantiation. Examples: 

     final Type<Map<String, List<String>>> mapStringToListOfStringType
         = new Type<Map<String, List<String>>>() { };
 
     final Type<String> stringType
         = new Type<String>() { };

    If, as in the last case, a simple class already fully defines the type concerned, there is a convenience method to get a corresponding Type instance. Example: 

     final Type<String> stringType
         = Type.of(String.class);

    See Also:
    Type(), of(Class)

      • getActualParameters

        public final List<Type<?>> getActualParameters()

        Returns the actual type parameters defining this Type.

        The result may be empty even if the formal parameter list is not. Otherwise the formal and actual parameter list are of the same size and order.

        See Also:
        getFormalParameters()

      • getMemberType

        public final Type<?> getMemberType(Type type)
        Converts a (possibly generic) Type that exists in the underlying class of this Type into a definite Type (like this).
